Trial_Design.evidence: The patients were divided into two groups those who underwent supra-annular (n=59) and intra-annular (n=54) AVR.

Participants.evidence: Between 2013 and 2019, 113 patients (77 males; mean age 57.8±16.36 years) who underwent isolated AVR were evaluated.

Intervention.evidence: The patients were divided into two groups those who underwent supra-annular (n=59) and intra-annular (n=54) AVR.

Objective.evidence: Objectives: This study aims to compare the early results of patients who underwent isolated aortic valve replacement (AVR) with supra-annular and intra-annular AVR.

Method_Outcome.evidence: There was no significant difference between the two groups in the postoperative first-week transthoracic echocardiographic (TTE) findings.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between 2013 and 2019, 113 patients (77 males; mean age 57.8±16.36 years) who underwent isolated AVR were evaluated.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The patients were divided into two groups those who underwent supra-annular (n=59) and intra-annular (n=54) AVR.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The cross-clamp (XCL) and cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) times of the patients who underwent supra-annular AVR were found to be significantly higher than the patients who underwent intra-annular AVR.

Harms.evidence: However, there was no significant difference between the two groups in terms of postoperative adverse events.
